If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

the noise is just on two layers, each with clip studio's perlin noise filter: one's layer mode is set to linear light, opacity at ~10%, with the filter scale at 2.0-2.5 so that it looks "blocky"; other one's set to soft light so it doesn't appear in white areas, opacity ~70%, with the filter scale at the minimum so it looks "noisy".

Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. >Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479346
a good typist can locate the right key instantly and without looking when you tell him the letter, however if you ask what the Xth key in the Yth row is it'll take him a minute
the point is, it's not about understanding the process thoroughly. you just need to develop the right hand/eye coordination, which is achieved by looking at the screen while drawing on the tablet and your brain gradually making links between the two over time
it's even easier if your cursor follows the stylus when you're only hovering over the tablet

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6478013
I am also a late starter. I started at the age of 29 and even went to art school after. The difficulties are mostly psychological in nature. I was already established in my field, made good money and was regarded as a high achiever in things that required a logic/math oriented mind. Starting out people chuckled at my trash art, they saw it in contrast to my wagie achievements and also even felt safe to shit talk me, because "I could take it right?".
Things got worse when I went to art school to try to become pro at some point. The school itself was great, and I didnt mind meeting younger people better than me, it was actually a blast. The bad part are family, partners, friends who actively discourage you "from throwing your life and talent away". This continues to this day, I am 36 now and a decent artist. Yes I don't earn nearly as much as I did, but I am happy and don't feel depressed anymore. Still get offers from people in STEM "to come work" with them. It's meant well, but I can't help but feel hurt by the fact that the people closest to me think what I am doing is kind of a joke and they are still waiting for me to "snap out of it" and get a real job.
Just be prepared to find new art friends and be humble again. You will go from high regarded normie to nobody overnight. You will most likely not get support from the people you think who would, even worse you will get discouragement throughout. This, paired with the fact that you will have low confidence at first (because you are bad and even young kids are better than you) makes it incredibly hard to make it. Good thing is, it's all in your head, it's a psychological challenge, the neuroplasticity crap is bullshit, I caught up to everyone quickly.

>>6479322
I will tell from my expirience. I've been drawing since childhood. Didn't go in artscool or art classes. I drew cartoons, anime, some of my fantasies. My classmates thought that I was good at drawing, my parents also praised me. I thought I was good, when in reality I just drew like a child who loves to draw. In each class there are at least 1-2 such children. You know these guys, or maybe you were them.
With age, I began to draw less and less, by the age of 18-19 I drew maybe a couple of times a year.
But one time I needed to draw pictures for my text rpg, and god, I realized how shitty of this i was.
This caused me great pain, never in my life i hated and despised myself more.
So I took courses in academic drawing and painting. I was 27 at the time.
Now I'm 31 and I still continue my education. By no means do I claim that I am a good artist now, I am not even close, but I see my growth with each work.

So, in my opinion, drawing as a child gives only two good things:
1. Fine motor skills develop.
2. You go through the drawing phase for fun as a teenager.

The first catches up very quickly, in just a couple of lessons you will already be good friends with a pencil/stylus.

The second point is what breaks many adult beginners.

The realization that before you start drawing your fantasies, you have to go through the hard and boring part. And it may take years. Those who have been drawing since childhood already had their fun. They have drawn cute anime girls, robots, disney princesses and monsters.They understand that it will not get better. And they will have to suffer. And accept it more humbly.

All this, of course, does not apply to those who studied in art schools as children, and then continued their studies in art at a college or university. These guys are gods and we will never catch up with them.

In my case, for example, I just detest the process of painting. So AI has almost no use for me beyond references, ideas, and similar indirect usage.

It's like how images of real things can be photographed or made by hand. The choice to use a machine to take a picture is what many people do, but landscape artists (painters, illustrators and more) still do what they do. Digital vs trad also is a similar situation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6449833

/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6478746
light broken lines, or flat values, no detail, that ez

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479665
For me, I am most productive when I do a big batch of pages assembly line style-I pencil 10-20 pages, then ink, then do shading and effects, then letters.
Inking takes the longest for me. I'm trying to work on making my pencils clean enough that I can skip the inking step but I'm a ways away from that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479670
Yeah I do that as well.
I always think that the reader will look at every panel the same way I do, when that's not even close to the truth.
The average reader will maybe spend 1-2 seconds looking at a single panel.
Obviously, really big panels or something like a 2 page spread will get more attention from the reader but for a normal panel, detail isn't needed.
Also you get a much bigger 'wow'-effect when your normal panels have little detail and look simple and then your big and important panels are full of detail and shading etc.

When I read manga/comics I sometimes spend more time looking at the speech bubbles and reading the dialogue compared to looking at the characters, let alone the backgrounds of each panel.

But I get it. You want to go all out and show what you're capable of, even in normal, boring panels.
Restraining your power level and knowing when to go all out takes practice and skill.

>>6463841
I got in the industry by founding my own gaming company with colleagues and being employed there with an artist role. So not really your typical way of getting into the industry, but definitely one with the brightest future I would say. Would recommend over chasing jobs and clients your whole career.
But if you want to get into the industry, don't send the same portfolio to dozens of clients. Tailor it to their needs, show them that you want to do the "dirty" jobs as well. For example, if you want to do concept art, don't just put up flashy images of soldiers (they got enough people who want to do that) but rather lots of concepts for mundane objects that will fill their game world. But really, it depends on what kind of industry you want to get into

The lesson here OP, seeing as you're new to this and all, is:
Always conduct any prospective business interactions over email. If you don't have an email you would feel confident in sending out to clients, make one. If anyone messages you through DMs/messages/comments/etc. Tell them to message you through your email.

It's for your protection and theirs. That way if they want to discuss anything sensitive that goes against the policy of whatever social media you're using, you don't get the rug pulled from under you like it just did. It likely happened because the retard didn't want to use kofi and wanted to use paypal so they would have some sort of financial protection incase they weren't happy with their commission or some stupid shit like that. Always look out to protect yourself, OP. You had the right idea by going with kofi over paypal.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6482018
As an artist whose tried both, I highly respect artists who can pull off bw. It's actually so much more difficult than colored, because there are so many abstractions and design choices you have to study up on to make it work. With color, it's much more representative of real life.

>>6482022
I'm not actually so sure color takes that much longer. If you look at most manga, there's a huge amount of hatching going on. A page could take 10 hours if a single person worked on it. I guess it depends on the art-style, though.

On top of that, bw comics are much harder to manage assistants on, because you have to create instructions and documents to get them to do what you envisioned. With coloring, you can just hire a colorist, whose sole responsibility is coloring

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Colour adds infinitely more room for fuckups for only a marginal gain, and in my opinion comics with very intricate colouring actually get tiresome to look at after a while. Black and white or simpler colour(like limited palettes or something like Blacksad or Tintin) are much better for the actual reading experience.
Sometimes colour can help salvage readability when the original art was sloppy with composition and values, like some of the worse panels in Jojo parts 5 and 6, but that's the best I can say about those coloured versions. They look putrid. In general it's less unpleasant to sit through mediocre BW, because mediocre colour like digital airbrush or garish webtoon shit lowers the art as a whole, just look at the butchered right version in picrel.
So to answer the question, I prefer BW or simple on grounds of how comfortable they are to read, since they're harder to fuck up and I prefer comics that prioritise the flow of the narrative over making good individual "illustrations"(Alex Ross is a good artist but his comics feel very awkward to me)
Colour can be good but it's a whole new dimension of complexity added on top and if rushed it's often too generic to add to the storytelling, and by necessity if it doesn't have anything of meaning to add to the whole it'll detract from it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6482084
Limited colour is pretty good but there's something to be said for the harsh contrast of BW, maybe paired with some grey values. It's very captivating and a whole tradition in and of itself, even back from the days of oldtimey book illustrations, and I think it's one of the reasons japanese comics are so successful. It makes for very immersive reading, I suggest checking out the bit about colour and BW in McCloud's Understanding Comics. I think it ties into the whole bit at the start about cartoonier characters being closer to meaning and text than they are to literal representations, so BW leaves more room for imagination and thus emotional attachment from the reader. Colour is more flashy and eye-catching to the general public, but it's not like they're a very enduring audience and anyone familiar with comics will be receptive to BW unless they're some capeshit consoomer.

posts.com:
The only advantage Wacom still has in the screenless tablet market is build quality, and even then that's the least of your concerns outside of XP-PEN loose nib, which Huion and even fucking Ugee have fixed.
And with Ugee the only concern is fast wear and tear, outside of that while it works, it works as good as any intuos, but considering how goddamn cheap it is that's hardly an issue.

And that's what this Wacomfag doesn't understand, nobody questions that Wacom is still the best drawing tablet maker in the market for a whole list of reasons. The question is if Wacom's worth the price, and the answer has been a solid NO for at least 3 years.
Why pay 200% the price at times for a 10~17% improvement in quality from the nearest competitor, which in most cases it barely affects the actual drawing experience, and it balances out in life expectancy of the product anyways?

>>6471222
>Are they worth the exorbitant price tag?
Depends on what you're looking for. The Cintiq Pro 27 is the most natural feeling tablet I have ever used in some 20+ years, where working on it really removes that nagging feeling of having to double check your strokes before you make them thanks to how accurate marks are to your intent.
For the average person that can barely hold a pen to begin with and thinks that making 1248 wrong strokes but ctrl+z'ing after every one of them until they get the "right" stroke, no you probably won't be able to appreciate the difference.
But if you work with analogue mediums regularly because of how responsive they are and miss that when moving to digital systems, yes you very well might find the latest Wacom gear worth the price.

The biggest/newest wacom/huion/xp pen you can find 2nd hand. This is the option I would go for personally, but some people are weird about used stuff.
If you want mobile, you might be able to find a used 3rd gen ipad pro for that, and can definitely find a used 1st or 2nd gen + pencil for under $300.
If you need new, a refurbished kamvas pro 16 is about $240, or a refurbished base model 22 (antiglare screen protector instead of etched glass, and worse color gamut compared to the pro or plus) is $280.
If you don't want used or refurbished, kamvas pro 13 is $280.
I've never personally tried ugee or gaomon so I don't know how good they are, but their 16" displays are both $280.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479265
I would suggest just getting one of these bed desks and see how it works for you first, make sure to check the dimensions before buying. A portable desk you can fold and slide away should be useful for your small living space either way.

If you find it too uncomfortable and would rather spend the money, then your options would be a galaxy tab s6 ~ s8 / ipad or some kind of surface laptop.

A display tablet that plugs into the laptop can complicate the situation, and be uncomfortable to move around with from all the cables and the larger size, especially if you use a lot of hotkeys and still need a keyboard.

I'd really try the desk first and worry later. Better is subjective, people have been making art with whatever tools they have available for ages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460515
It's good that you took the time to finish it. Think of the first parts of the drawing step as being more important to the final work than anything else. Check all of your proportions to your reference, and when you aren't sure about something then you'll know what gaps in your knowledge you have to fill in. Be very careful not to simply copy what you see without thinking about it, as you'll grow very fast by being mindful of what you're doing. Keep finishing your painting like you've done here, and enjoy it. Keep sharing it with us.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460526
With the grid. I just draw the important outlines. the pencil lines would be as detailed as this pic from google. Important contours such as the clavicle would also be marked with a line.
I take advantage of the very fast drying time of acrylic paint, I can just slather on colours without regard if it actually matches the reference image and I'll fix it on subsequent layers. This is why I prefer it to oil.

Soz bro, either you've been scammed or you're mistaken, oils never dry this fast no matter the medium. The oils always win on unprimed paper not the other way around. After some time (not instantly) you would see oilstains everywhere. But if you're not worried about archiving your work while you're still practicing you shouldn't really have to worry. Nicolas Uribe does it often, he talks about painting on a budget aswell if you're intrested. I think he's mostly lazy tho :)
Prepping with acrylic gel medium as a buffer works well, it's cheaper than gesso and dries faster I just love spreading it on cardboards and whatever I can find

>>6463510
I like your technique

That said, other anon is right, do a few value exercises to warm up first. You seem to get lost along the way somewhere. Which is interesting bc I also see a sense of focus and order, especially palette wise.

So I'll keep it short:
> values
> edges
> foreground/background. Try to find a way where I can squint my eyes and differentiate between the two
> detail. this overlaps with foreground and edges

You seem to be well aware of your recurring mistakes so I think you'll be fine. I'm pretty confident everyone has their own personal Achilles heel tho. Hope this helps

>>6480078
Thank you.
I'll post the palette that I used for anyone who's interested in figure painting.

Titanium White
Crimson
Burnt Umber
Raw Sienna
Yellow Ochre
Naples Yellow
Light Olive Green (Wallpaper in the background)
Ultramarine (To mix with Burnt Umber to produce black and darker browns)

Brand
Liquitex Basics or Artist's Loft (Cheapest legit art store paint).

Mixing is done on the fly on a glass palette with the same brush used for painting, no palette knife is used. A 1 cm angular flat brush is used for the body and face. A larger 1-inch flat brush is used for the background.

To summarize I think you're working with a poor reference of a woman who's had a lot of plastic surgery.
You won't get a drawing that looks right using her as reference.
The pose is also a little too symmetrical to translate into a good drawing.
You should also avoid those unconfident lines when doing lineart. Practice drawing clean lines in a single stroke.
Hope this helps.

Forgot to mention you should also study line weight.
Lines closer to the light source or further from the viewer should be thinner and vice versa.

yeah this is what I meant ( or at least tried to). where I see many people failing animating by mesh is:
1. only using linear interpolation, so lack of weight
2. using the same images/parts in for the whole
cycle, this limit the expressiveness and force of action.

If you are interested try doing this for the tits and pussy lips have 3 distinct images (idle, pushing max position and pulling min position) use the idle for the most part of the animation and in the finishing the movement of pull/push change the image (and possibly also the mesh and vertexes)

t. old opentoonz dev and helped a few people with this kind of animation

>>6477669
Oh I've seen your art before outside 4chan. Nice to see you here and I'm glad you are working on improving.

On the subject of the hair - you can think of it like ribbons that start from specific points and flow outwards from there. I noticed in your other drawing near the start of the thread you seem to draw it as an outline - try using the ribbon method, or doing it "chunks".

For the bodies, you may need to examine the shoulder area a bit more. The delts feel rather small for how ripped they are and that's probably what's throwing people off.

Specifically for the one I replied to - the male character's arm that's closer to the camera looks smaller than the one that's farther. There's also some issue with the lines of his torso where everything is straight horizontal in line, which reduces dynamicism and can draw attention to the areas you may not want.

The facial expressions look mostly fine to me, that seems like a stylistic deliberate choice. And I do think the girl's boobs are hanging mostly properly.

Keep it up, semi-hyper dicks and muscular characters is a good niche.

posts.com:
>>6474228
I’ve gone through several phases of ‘fun pen’

many years ago I liked the 005 micron because it was so fine, and felt sexy to use. But it is completely impractical to sketch with because the nib wears down so fast.

Then i upgraded my paper from cheap copy paper to heavy smooth card stock. I was super into the 01 micron, until I discovered the plastic nib PN micron. The PN is super robust, and you can get some line weights with it. It draws fast and is my favorite sketching pen.

I used the PN until a buddy got me into using a 2mm lead holder with HB lead. Now for quick sketches I use the lead holder and went back to cheap copy paper. The toothy paper feels really good with the pencil.

Recently, I went back to the 005 on the smooth copy paper for some studies (pic rel). The 005 felt just as good as I had remembered, but you really need to be purposeful and you can’t just dick around and make scribbles or the nib turns to a nub.

Here is the list of pens I thought I would like, but find infuriating
>pocket brush pen
Fuck this thing. It’s too slow, the line weight is nice, but the ink is so thin and weak, I’d rather use a dip pen. I also hate the wavy hand tremors that show up when i draw with it. Definitely not for sketching

>dip pen
The worst pen. The learning curve is just way too high. I spent 2 yrs trying to ink with it. It’s even slower than the brush pen because you have to clean the tip and dip every 2 minutes. Then wait for the ink to dry so you don’t smear it. Probably the most unfun pen I’ve ever used. I never have a good time inking with it. The ink is either too thick or too thin or the nib is worn, the ink splatters, and my desk is covered in soggy ink soaked tissues like I just jerked off a swarm of squid.

Pens:
>Faber Castell B, SC, and SB
Pretty great brush pens, although SC and SB are the most fun for me.
>Kuretake Bimoji brush pens
also big favorites of mine although I use the biggest brushes the most.

If you're into sumi-e or want a lot of variety in line width while inking then I recommend giving them a try. I especially like to sketch in these when I'm feeling a little mischievous.

Pencils:
>Pentel 0.5 mm (205)
Pretty cheap and fun to make more precise linework in. Feels really sharp. Use this the most for practicing more technical work/studies.
>Mitsubishi 2B pencil
I love to sketch in this the most, especially for thumbnails or more gestural work. It's smooth like butter and feels great to draw in. Though they get pretty small fairly quickly due to how soft the lead is so I definitely recommend getting a pencil extender if you buy a pack (I just use General's)

>>6465082
>What kind of benefits are you looking for?
>In this case, what do You want out of art?
I honestly don't know. I just get ideas that I think are worth realizing (but require very different skill sets to execute). I get super hyped for the final product, I finish it, and then reality sets in.
I'm asking /fag/ for advice because /fag/ at least seems to enjoy what they do.

I don't know if I do what I do out of boredom, delusions of grandeur or what. When I finish something, I get thoughts like "oh, well that was a waste of time and nobody cares about it, I should have spent this time doing something else". But then I get the next idea, and the cycle starts again.

I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.

It could be general negative thoughts from not having close friends or social status, but that's not easily fixed. It's difficult for me to build a circle around my hobbies because I jump ship too often to really "get good" at things (and being a /pol/cel doesn't help).

If I was smart, I would channel this energy into making some kind of soulless moneymaking machine, but alas. I can't learn to be content with vidya, weed and anime porn like normal people.

I think the TL;DR is that I keep chasing the dragon trying to make the next big thing, but I get easily discouraged and don't stick with things or chase trends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465582
It sounds like you're surrounding yourself with negative situations that'll never happen. Instead, why even worry about what ifs and just concern yourself about those issues Once you get to them (if they even ever come up). Overall, you're just over thinking and allowing your mind to wonder about possible negative outcomes that'll just never happen.
>I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.
I used to have this type of emotion. But in my case, I'd complete a drawing, be happy with it, and convince myself that I can never make anything as good ever again, and take me hours (sometimes days) to get the courage to draw up something again. I repeat this cycle upon each drawing, but now when I hear that voice I let it hang out with me. Instead of feeling doom, I'm just like "lmao you might be right" and just start on the next drawing soon after.
Overall, these emotions are gonna be hard to defeat. But instead of removing them, try to be friends with them. And you'll see why said emotions are making you think the way you are. Otherwise, you really have nothing to lose.

>>6472047
drawing furry stuff has leveled up my ability to draw figures so much because I want them to be in particular poses and have interesting designs. When just studying or producing other art I don't exercise the imagination muscle. Whereas furry stuff is like intense training of that muscle. And you quickly see when you're not doing well because people won't marvel at a well rendered furry image with no imaginative design/pose/whatever. It's really cool and interesting and I'm glad I got into it. You can see just in this thread how creative furries are because they're always exercising that muscle, and doing so in a fun way

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6472814
I'm >>6464532
and I've had some thoughts on the subject since I posted.

If one's parents are furries and this information is concealed from children, it would probably stem from concern regarding an audience.

>Child viewing parents
The earliest role models of competence in a child's life is the parents (and most impactful in most cases) and the goal of the parents (presuming care and responsability) is to guide the child's growth to become something functional to society, and also the audience/environment of schools.

Furry parents probably would withhold this because there's a lot of different places/people one may end up hanging out with within the fandom given that there's a huge output of porn and some very vocal weirdos that drown out the more normal ones.

Word getting out to a kid's friends might also make the "Anon's parents are weirdos" and lead to potential embarrassment from peers.

The parents also do not yet know what their child's likes/dislikes are and given that they will be housing the child for 18 or more years, everyone being cohesive is important, both nuclear family and external.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474152
hopefully someone will give you better pointers but from my limited understanding:
1. line width counts, use width to accent different areas, currently your whole drawing uses a total of 2 different thicknesses for outline + detail lines
2. you need to use more lines to define shapes, normally you'd do this with shading which you have done and is nice but that should be a *secondary* component, every region that has any roundness whatsoever and pops out from the perspective of the "camera" could have a line to accent it, like on the butts, on the face around the cheeks etc.
check a *lot* of cel-shaded art and do studies on simple objects to get a feel for it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474152
>>6474199
Cel-shading is just consolidating a range of values into a few shades. So studying values in general will give you the skills you need to reduce them down.
As with any skill, it's better to cultivate the proper foundation before you start trying to simplify things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Make drawing time Special...

Isolate yourself, and put that phone on airplane mode. Clear room on a flat surface and have adequate lighting for your work surface,so the rest of the room,and all their distractions, are hidden in darkness. Have a beverage handy, and a lot of it,too,safely away from where you are working. And light some incense or at least some pleasantly scented candle.

Use "good" materials. Don't draw on lined paper,or on scraps. Spring for a sketchbook of versatile paper and have more to hand. Use a good grade of ballpoint,ONLY BLACK INK. Or,if you like pencils, have a few dozen pre sharpened so all you need do is reach out for a new one if you wear down the point of your current tool.

Lastly,put on some music. Mood music:instrumental without lyrics to influence your own ideas. Have the tunes match your intent. And most of all....EXPLORE. Let the mind wander,let the hand drift alone the page,and see where you both are led together. Don't be discouraged if what you start fails your expectations:that is what sketchbooks are for,exploring and designing. Have fun. The only way to get better at drawing is BY drawing. Avoid /ic/ and their obsession with Loomis and craft. Find your own Voice. And enjoy the journey.

>>6475812
I made a webcomic about myself. Ive probably made about 150 strips in the past 2 years. Stop finding excuses to start and just put something on paper. It’s definitely one of those things you learn as you go and not something you can read up about. You can always restart it after figuring things out.

I’ve made 0 dollars. I have like 20 followers. I get 1-2 likes per comic. I made it for myself. Nobody really likes it except for me.

Biggest mistakes: wasting time uploading it on social media platforms and tagging it with useless hashtags. I got kicked off webtoons pretty fast, i had a twitter and an IG that take way too much effort to maintain. I was spending more time trying to publish it and get it out on different platforms than actually making the content. It was a futile effort to try to post it online. There is so much noise that you are drowned out in seconds after posting content. Like you are trying to whisper to your friend from across a death metal concert.

These responses have webcomic hosting sites like Webtoon Canvas and Tapas in mind. If you self-host, then do whatever you want but it's a ton more work
1. Yes, because you want people to start reading and subscribing right away. if you only make a one shot, then why come back?
2. I mean a closed story. Don't try to make your first webcomic your magnum opus, start small. Most people never get past the pre-production stage and get so wrapped up in world building and character concepts that they never make the comic. Keep it simple, understand the workflow, and then move on to more complex stories.
3. Don't use this site for starters. Get used to posting on social media, like WIPs, etc. Participate in collaborations with other creators, shill on Discord, and Reddit (in the appropriate places). Just don't spam and follow the rules if you use Reddit. Absolutely do not use this site to gain fame unless you're ready for an influx of pizzas
4. Follow big creators on Twitter and subscribe to webcomic related subreddits. Sometimes big creators need help with background assistants, inks, color flats, etc. Even Webtoons posts jobs for assistants. Don't expect a lot of cash from this though, working in webcomics is a lot of work with crunch deadlines. Even creators (like pic related) take advantage of their assistants, too. If you want to go through this route, have a portfolio of examples. If you 100% want a webcomic job, learn 3D modeling and get good at Sketchup and 3D modelling to make backgrounds. Custom background makers are a godsend in webcomics.

It depends on the amount of control you have, not on the medium. With photoshop, you are using the machine as a tool while doing the bulk of the work yourself. With SD, the only thing you control is the prompt you type but you have little control over the actual output besides choosing one that's "good enough". That's why copyright claims over ai artwork keep getting denied on the basis of not having been made by a human and that's also why SD can produce "art" even if you type nothing.

Obviously things get more complicated with people using ai as only part of their work (like for a background) but let's be real, most proompters are interested in quick results, they're not gonna bother with anything non-ai generated anyway

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6476963
It's actually really hard. You have to consider how a word is used in the zeitgeist of when the data for the model was put together.
A lot of effects can occur from combining phrases and simple tags, using underscores vs not, and so on. There's ways to generate coherent things using terms so unrelated it seems schizophrenic.

The difference between emphasizing a tag vs repeating it also occurs. Adjusting the scale and steps, the sampler, if you used img2img precisely how much denoising strength to use, whether you've applied textual inversion or not, and so on.

Even then the phrases and tags require lateral thinking.
During training the dataset used images' alt text for associating words with concepts. Like, you get interesting effects from using phrases that mimic clickbait articles because of how much of the dataset derives from images whose alt text was just article titles similar to:
>"doctors say you should eat this superfood"

There's also cases where you want to lean heavier on the negative prompts vs the prompt portion, and vice versa. Some things when put in one make the image nicer but ruin it if in the other and vice versa. It's not as simple as putting "1girl" in the prompt and "1boy" in the neg to make a female character and swapping them to make a male character, you have to understand those phrases are the TOTALITY OF COMMON FEATURES between images that would be tagged with each. They may not even be necessary at all!

This shit is exhausting when you get deeper into it to the point where you realize nobody is going to pay someone to sit there trying to generate a perfect image over 3, 5, (9??) hours? However long it takes to get it close enough. It's more useful for brainstorming ideas.

But to say it's easy misses the point - you can get "something" sure, but getting "the right thing" is hard.

When I generated picrel, it was far from what I wanted. But it's useful now to add emphasis to my post at least.

>>6478744
It actually is, not physically but mentally. If your goal is to try to make something non-generic and cohesive.

The basic prompts people were having fun with when dall-e mini was the big thing like "shrek meeting the pope" don't produce specifics, they produce generics. If you wanted say, them to be meeting in a cafe you have to specify that. If you want the pope laughing you have to specify that too. If you want shrek crying - and on top of all this these things can produce bad outputs. Say you trying to get the pope laughing makes him... not the pope. Say it makes him stand up, or completely changes the scene.

As I explained, the AI works off of "averages", it doesn't know what specific elements of an image are. It only knows roughly what data is common between words. So you're trying to get the intersection of many averages to reach a specific point that accurately produced an image you want. It's very hard, especially when trying to design characters - you may think you have it, and then in your process of trying to adjust the last few elements the entire design falls apart.

On top of that you need artistic knowledge of some kind to know certain terms to use (like "dutch angle" if you want/don't want it), as well as curating the output.

Machines are retarded, and I'm very in touch with my inner computer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thoughts from someone who has beginner experience with lots of things.

>Pencil
Kino. Nothing beats a regular pencil on printer paper. Limitless medium. Main tool I use, always carry a pencil with me everywhere I go. Cheap color pencil like crayola is easy for quick coloring. Expensive color pencils work nicely with mixed media.

>Charcoal and conte
Love charcoal on newsprint. Use it not only for figures but also for sketching whatever comes to my mind. The effects of charcoal and conte are very unique and I like the look of fluid and gestural drawings in charcoal.

>Ink
Kino. Great medium and so much you can do with just ink and black and white. Both ink pen and wash are nice and I love the smell of ink.

>Oil
So much you can do with it from simple to incredibly complex. The luminosity of paints and the way layers shine through each other is beautiful. A medium that really is fantastic but takes a lot of thought and consideration into brush strokes, colors, temperature, drying time, even how much paint you load to make a good painting. Can start to become very expensive when buying mediums and more colors. Using a few tubes limits the color range you can get as you lose chroma from mixing but I'm pretty sure there are some painters who use translucent layering from pure colors to get bright effects and having layers shine through together without needing to mix colors directly at all that they wouldn't be able to get from mixing. Slow drying.

>Acrylic
Hard medium but a great challenge. I don't like the way colors look through layering but it might be a competency issue. Not as beautiful as oil but acrylic is good for mixed media and you can use different mediums with acrylic for different effects and it dries much faster.

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479847
>Watercolor
Easy for anyone to pick up but hard to get good. I like the look of washes and translucent layers. Cheaper than and dries fast. I have trouble with drying times and the way my brushstrokes look because of it. Love it.

>Gouache
Really bad with it. I like to use it opaque like with acrylic, but you can definitely use it with translucent layers. When I paint opaque with it my brush picks up the layer underneath because gouache reactivates very easily from water, which gives me awful colors, and trying to get around this with a thicker paint stroke makes my surface and layers uneven and thick giving them unintended texture. When using opaque strokes I lose values and chroma so I cannot reach the color notes I could get with translucent layering over the whiteness of the paper, or maybe I just don't know how to mix gouache I don't know. I'm still keen on using it to improve but it is very hard.

>Oil pastel
It's ok, I used it for mixed media once. Gives an unique look.

>Digital
Efficient and easy to clean up. Can reach color notes easily, but I prefer the color of oil paints and watercolor over digital colors and layering. I don't like using digital for lineart either, prefer to use a real pen instead. I don't like staring at blue light and prefer traditional because I'm a tactile person and like the feeling and smell of traditional tools. Digital is great for pumping things out quickly though but trying to spend for than 10 hours on a digital piece is a chore meanwhile with traditional I can easily spend more time on it.

>Sculpting
Worked with natural clay, polymer clay, and monster clay before. I don't like monster clay because of the way you need to heat and dry to use it, the other two are fine. Not good at sculpting but I like it, working with it feels fantastic and I love watching sculpting videos.

>Digital sculpting
I tried zbrush before, didn't like it a lot. I prefer feeling what I'm working with when sculpting.

(2/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479669
I use 4B pencils because it combines the best balance between erasability and control of darkness/lightness while also being less smudge-prone and dirty than softer pencils
I use acid-free cardstock from an industrial-supplier because it's the cheapest I could find while still being great for my uses.
I use Copic pens as they're refillable, feel better than micron and are guaranteed compatible with markers (future-proofing, haven't gotten any markers yet)
I use a big ancient screenless tablet because it still works great and looks cooler than modern ones.

My erasers consist of a soft dust-free one for cleaning big areas and a magic rub for details. I use an eraser shield for the details and the big area one is too soft for it. The magic rub does this strange "smudge until it suddenly cleans it" which is less efficient for large areas, but it's firm enough to accurately clean the small ones.

I also use a pencil extender to keep nubs working until they're unsharpenable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473037
He's showing the front plane of the pectorals. This plane is bounded laterally by a line from the clavicle (specifically, the point on the front at which the clavicle curves backward) to the bottom outer limit of the pectoral (just a little below/outside the nipple). From that bottom/outer point, an oblique line going toward the point of the shoulder is the base of another triangular plane, which is the side plane of the pectoral.

Shit tier. Or at least that's the trauma left by my mother.

>Anime
>Waste of life
>Video Games
>Low tier
There are dozens of reaction channels on youtube doing nothing but watching and reacting to anime. Is there a lot of risk and for many, not any earnings? Yes, but is low effort.

Drawing is high effort, low earning, anti-social, and boring and soon enough obsolete thanks to AI, which unlike any of the above hobbies, the AI doesn't need to learn to emulate charisma.

good tier - anything that requires you to learn a skill and keep on learning for the rest of your life to improve at.
mid tier - Things that are more like disciplines than something you continuously learn. but also still very worth your time whether for health, protection, or mental stimulus
shit tier - anything that's basically just a game, requires no learning, or you're just learning trivial information and doesn't require you to do anything beyond that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473866
Never saw that drawing, but the torso looked blobby to me, and the belly looked rather concave because of the values you used. Also the hips seemed a bit iffy to me. Pic has the value shapes you used in red and blue is the implied form. The belly definition was just my personal preference. You can blur the abs and it wouldn't really matter. About the light, here's a tip, when you compare the rgb sliders of an unlit area and a lit one, and one of the sliders moves in the opposite direction of the rest, there's something strange going on. The exception is when the lit area is the shadow area of another light or when you're straight up changing hues. This is not a hard rule, but something to think about.

>>6477580
I just canceled my sub.

I really disliked the format. Also having drawn for a few years I knew most of the intro classes already but the big issue is there’s lots and lots of droning on and on about nothing and tons of empty space.

Basically they try to pace it like a real life class, but without any time for you to actually work. As a result most instructors just talk for 4 hours about things that could easily be condensed down to like a 10 minute YouTube video.

It’s just not worth the money imo. Some of the classes themselves are fine and the instructors are telling you correct information. It’s just painfully padded out to increase the video times and there’s very little there you wouldn’t find on YouTube for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477580
>>6477593
This. In a 10 hour course you will have 9 hours of filler. The only good courses are the Vilppu and Steve Huston Courses.

The owner, Joshua Jacobo, said in an interview he doesn't allow his teachers to edit any of their classes, because he wants the students to see that the "teachers also make mistakes", but this results in an endless droning on and rambling about nothingness. It's especially bad when they start demoing, because they'll just stop talking and draw.

Get the Vilppu course, then bail.

>>6481517
If you're not doing courses in person then they're garbage.
Courses are good because of the interaction and direct instruction you get, plus it actually forces you to work on things.

Online courses give you none of that. You just get a glorified youtube video. In which case, just watch any major art youtuber. SInix is good if you want general anatomy tips and direct to the point instruction.
At the end of the day 99% of art is drawing and learning how to draw the thing you want by looking at references. Courses will never change this because every good course will give you 5 minutes of instructions then tell you to draw for 3 hours.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

posts.com:
I think I might be too dumb to learn perspective.
I'm practicing perspective to learn to draw scenarios according to Dong Ho Kim's Space Drawing Perspective book, at some point it tells us to practice with real photographs and try to identify the vanishing points and practice drawing it.
Easy enough, I can put the vanishing points at eye level and sketch the general scenario, but when I'm trying to add detail, I realize that there are objects in the scenario that don't fit the existing vanishing points, and rather they seem to have their own, so I must have missed these vanishing points at the beginning, and then I get overwhelmed. Am I inherently retarded, or what am I doing wrong?

For example, picrel, it immediately jumps to me as a one point perspective, squarely centered, that's why I chose it, it was easy, but then look at the chairs on the floor or the bench near the camera, if I try to draw them in this one point perspective they become all wonky, so there's another point I'm missing, so I put another point in the horizon, but now the whole piece has two perspective points, so it must be a two point perspective, but now then the scenario becomes wonky if I try to fit it.
Or is it that there's TWO one point perspectives? How does that happen? Am I overthinking it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6481188
In that picture with the table im sure youll find that theres three points of perspective. Yes there can be more then one and thats our reality. The first perspective you lay down is more or less the bases for the hallway and the other two perspectives are helpful for the furniture. Because furniture does not always align with the first vanishing point
Im still a beg when it comes to perspective myself and the confusion is part of the learning process. I cant find a pic that truly shows what im trying to say but I found one that shows two points indoors. Indoor perspective is tricky.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479906
It's a good start, but I'd approach it from a few different angles. Your pic helps sketch out composition, basic values, and is quick.

I'd also learn perspective, design, dive deeper into color and value, and do studies/plein airs to learn more about light and nuance of everything in nature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Where do you find the textures for lingerie like in this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6481188
One VP perspective will hold true for objects that are PARALLEL. The sides of your bench are not parallel with the walls; therefore, it has its own Vanishing Point(s); however, those VPs will still be on the same horizon line, as you have found. Read Perspective Made Easy or Framed Perspective 1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
the eyebrows arent in sync with the eyes hence the delayed action feeling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
refine the chin placement it follows a rigid pathing make it follow some sort of smooth arch it'll look more natural that way
the bangs have a nice delayed action to them good job : D
also i'd suggest drawing the ears as well even if they're just place-holders cause they'll help keep the head shap from warping with each succesive frame
hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper

>>6460328
To understand the meaning of "Just Draw" one must first understand that the true definition of talent is the ability to learn how to do something well with little to no instruction.

Now that we have that definition out of the way, we can begin with why the "just draw" phenomenon exists and why some people are able to actually benefit from the "just draw" when others seem to find it to be a trap.

Once we understand the definition of talent, we can now see why the "just draw" phrase is thrown around as if it was the most enlightened advice ever given. It is not because it actually works for everyone but rather that it works for anyone who has an innate ability to draw--innate not meaning "born with" but rather a proclivity towards drawing that creates a natural ability to learn things.

In order for "just draw" to actually work, one must have talent in drawing. This talent will allow you to be able to draw for hours and learn from your work and mistakes without any instruction whatsoever--though instruction could never hurt. If one does not have talent in drawing, they must seek out help in order to improve or else they will stagnate as pointed out by this anon: >>6463757

Basically, if you don't have talent, learning to draw will much harder and even if you do end up attaining a certain level of skill, your art will never be as good as most of the worst works from artists that do have talent which is why you have to find a reason to actually pursue art. You have to have a purpose as to why you are pursuing it rather than just the blind ambition of being able to draw le cute animu grill.

The real question we need to ask here is that if you do not possess such talent, would you still continue to draw? That is the real question you need to ask yourself here. That will allow you to determine whether or not to continue or if you should just quit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The path to getting gud is not a straight one. You need to keep moving to see where your strengths and weak points are, while also developing the habit and discipline every good professional needs to have

I guess a "talented" and skilled chef can taste a dish, determine if it tastes good or bad on a very refined level, and based on prior experimentation and a knowledge of how various spices taste, be able to determine how the dish could be salvaged, or if unsalvageable, how to make it better next time. >>6471926
>The Process of Drawing
Here we go, I'll try to explain as best as I could.

The difference between being able to perform and being able to teach is based on the understanding on the process of that specific skill. Performers tend to not understand the process of being able to learn something and therefore are the worst teachers in that field. They tended to have received their skill by sheer mileage and have often taken decades to get to where they currently are. As they have not properly analyzed their approach and why they do certain things, they have an intuitive understanding of drawing which only helps them. Basically, performers cannot teach and can only perform. This is where you get the advice to "just draw" because performers tend to be the ones that actually take this advice seriously and tend to get good by sheer mileage rather than anything concrete that you can teach to anyone.

Teachers understand a skill at a much higher level than performers and while they may not be as good as the performers, they will often coach the performers regardless. Note how coaches in sports aren't usually better than the players on the team. (If they were, they'd be mentors not teachers or coaches.) A teacher must have a very high level of understanding of whatever skill they are pursuing as they have to properly explain each and every step--otherwise, they're wasting everyone's time.

For instance, if we were to bring this back to drawing, lets say a beginner creates a drawing. You notice that the drawing is shit but because you are a performer, you can't exactly explain why it is shit. You can say something like, "the forms are off" or the "perspective is off" but you can't really delve exactly as to why the drawing is really bad, much less provide useful resources to practice from.

The teacher will be able to hyper-analyze a drawing and know exactly what the issues are what that beginner to study.

Most people on here are performers, NOT teachers.

>>6472033
Chances are when someone is asking you how they can learn how to draw, especially on here where the entire board is literally dedicated to this one skill, that person has tried to draw and might've even tried to learn how to draw but because they are so new to drawing, they do not understand how to approach it.

Just Draw, to a beginner, implies that they just continue to draw their bad symbols over and over again until they eventually improve. It DOES NOT imply--as others have erroneously said--you objectively look at your drawings and analyze why they are bad. This is not something a beginner--especially those who started drawing late--will be able to do as they do not understand the process of drawing.

Because this is a board dedicated towards the critiquing of discussing of artwork, it was quite strange for me to discover that the only piece of advice that was thrown around was "just draw." When you pursue any other skill, you never hear anyone just say, "just play the piano" or "just sing" or "just code" etc. There are typically well defined fundamentals that even those who literally just started are going to be aware of such as playing the scales as a pianist or learning the absolute basics of coding--though coding is a bit arbitrary to be honest.

It wasn't until I started to draw a lot more that I realized that most people on here don't actually analyze what they are doing. They kind of treat it like a video game where they simply play and play and play the game until they maybe get good rather than sitting back and analyzing what strategies are the best, what their weak-spots are, and what is worth practicing. This isn't to say you focus too much on strategies, obviously there is a level of performance that must take place, but completely neglecting it for "just playing" or "just drawing" is quite ridiculous.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460328
since learning takes a bunch of time, the best advice they could give you is trust the years of hard work and eventually you'll see the results.

to get good results, it would make sense to analyze your piece after you've gained enough symbol making abilities and think (not emotionally, constructively)

> "OK, this I lack perspective skills"

this is quite simple to fix, perspective is very tactical, with enough grids you will see where you made a mistake, fix it, remember, draw enough to train your muscle memory and you'll draw buildings in perspective in no time,
if your hand is witty enough you can doodle something abstract in perspective. But to that you need to think with more IQ points,
there are some people breaking down every type of perspective while giving basic overalls on it, then apply into your art

>I don't know how to draw circular, soft shapes

from drawing a lot your hand should get smooth lines quite easily, practice drawing a circle, then lines curving around it, find other shapes from pictures and whatnot, draw a bunch of lines to understand the form, soon instead of blockiness you'll get smoothiness

hate shading? look at how it's done in real life, look at 2 values, thern add a rim light, then maybe really soft shapes with a lighter value, make sure to think how shapes reflect light,
find videos of light traveling across the room, going far and close to the object

you're an artist, and artist observes more than normal people, and if you wanna be a master, you gotta put in some studying into it as well

but never forget this, if you love drawing, you better draw your hands off and "just draw", and we promise you'll get gut

or take things slow, just remember to have fun in it too

More advice:

Stop being Afraid.

Mistakes,and bad execution will haunt you, but persevere in their despite. In my own case,what I present to the public is usually very different from the source material that I physically draw with ballpoint pens,and pencil for intentionally moulding into two dimensional sculpture that are my finished panels. But what I have "most" of are over 180 pages of a sprawling tale of Jeremey Prickles and a good 70 pages were literally storyboards of when I was able to Do It Properly, which means everything is made of separately drawn chunks pounded by Photoshop into story, So I drew it using the sketchbooks I was dragging into waiting rooms,and an epic story sprung from a random sketch of a demon head. It has both moments of revelation and whiplash pangs at your heart strings. I ordered a flatbed scanner so I can properly showcase my recent art,and the tale I am now telling,and the decision I have made. I am going to be 58 soon,and I am pondering how to proceed. I want to tell as many stories completely as I can, but I want to give the rendering enough work, to at least give a vague impression of what I was aiming for. To balance the art with the storytelling is a tightrope walk:in a page,I want to inch the story foward, at least from these current crop of characters (I had 3 storylines going at once,and all parties have joined up heading towards the end.). So I am just letting the story take me where it will. Yesterday I drew for the first time the daughter of two characters that were my Science fiction comics,a nearly extinct race of bipedal heavyworlder lizardfolk who fly with attached wingfolds under their arms,and they had retractable claws and 360o vision.

They met in a singles bar. Hey,6 was 14. Very 14. Well,there is their daughter stuck in fairy realms because she had the food there,and binds you to that realm. What the hell. Foward momentum!

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6472842
>>6471842
A lot of people don't have concrete ideas of what they want to draw, or even what they like a lot of the time. Sometimes this is due to a "copying is bad" mind poison, sometimes it's due to a false idea that to "be a master" means that drawing entirely from imagination is the skill to practice.

In general, though, it's that they haven't made a conscious effort to examine their own tastes to where they have anything to say. It can be a compartmentalization issue - happens with coomer artists a lot, where they filter everything "not sexy" into a different mental box and so put almost no new inspiration into their "sexy art box" on the daily.

It could also be a complete disconnect between what they like to consume and what they like to produce - for some, a motivation to create is because of a lack of met desires with what currently exists. In this case they need to examine LOTS of things to know what to "not" make, which by extension gives them the mental negative-space shape of what fits the criteria of what they DO want to make.

Finally, unrelated to the other two, some people really need ultra basic help. Proper posture/desk setup for maximum arm movement is what is missing when a lot of people don't get how to draw from your shoulder, for example. And "How to use a ruler to measure things while drawing" is another, since some people, again, fuck up their mental compartments and remove all other skills from the "drawing" box. The aforementioned inability to compare to reference accurately (along without understanding that tracing can be a tool to help) is another. These are all things that are even more basic than what people call "Fundamentals," they're the kind of shit that almost nobody teaches or talks about outside of an atelier or private instruction.

Most people outside of this hellhole that are parroting "just draw" are assuming that those they speak with are just suffering from a confidence issue like performance anxiety.

Pic rel

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477369
To expand on point 2 and 3:
Just because someone likes horror doesn't mean they want to draw horror. They may be consumed by loving horror, but want to draw say - something more like Hamtaro or Sanrio.

But if they absolutely can't bear interacting with those media, then they're in a tough spot. They need to really examine what they like in great detail. A structure that works is a venn diagram:

>What I can do as good as them (for beginners this will be mostly empty, this exercise is repeated yearly or every six months or so)
>What elements I want to copy from them
>What elements of theirs I don't want to incorporate into my work

So to continue the example, they may want to draw cute shit and use bold lines and huge eyes, but with some kind of "implied story threads" that are more like the cute, cozy energy found in drawings people do of POKEMON, not hamtaro or sanrio.

That's partly why asians seem like gods to newbie western artists. Writing in japanese, chinese or korean requires a lot of precision to be legible else you fuck it up. The very act of learning to write an asian script is training line quality from the first day in school, or beforehand.

In fact if you practice copying kana or hanzi you will find your line quality improve dramatically over weeks vs just drawing boxes or circles. You don't have to know wtf you're writing, just copying as accurately as possible. Focusing on the lines, not the meaning.

Posture is also huge as I mentioned here >>6477369

>>6478345
I used to have that fear and managed to turn it around. I just accepted w/e I was about to draw was going to be the worst drawing of my life, and realized that's a great thing, because if what I shit out is the worst I'll ever be, it means everything I make after it has to be better. I celebrated awful drawings, because I COULD tell they were mega shit, I could see obvious mistakes, and try to learn from them for w/e I tried next. The scariest thing (which I've yet to reach), is the point where you draw something, and are unable to see anything wrong with it. You see it often on this board, stubborn /beg/s posting deviantart OC tier trash and insisting nothing is wrong with it. If you know you suck, and what parts you suck at, you can take objectionable action.
The more you think about it, the more daunting it becomes, so just don't think and start filling pages, don't give those thoughts the time of day, spite them. When I finish a drawing, instead of focusing on the shit parts and being depressed, I'll go "hey, that hand didn't come out half bad, maybe I am improving" followed by "fuck you, fear of drawing, I finished another drawing, what the fuck you gonna do? huh? you still scared of drawing little bitch? lmao look at me I filled a page with confidence where you couldn't last year, and I'll do it again tomorrow". I take the same attitude towards shitters and crabs on this board. Every time I finish a drawing or study it's another victory against the faggots who tried to demoralize me and get me to quit. I've decided I'm gonna make it and that's that, anyone saying otherwise is wrong, even if it's my own subconscious. It's not even a question, therefore quitting is wrong, procrastinating is wrong, listening to doomers and AIfags is wrong, and every mark I'm putting down is proof of it.

Let me now interpret this rather glib phrase Just Draw :

To someone who has never drawn a line,I would advise that phrase,and this simple excercise...on a drawing pad of good quality, scribble on a page lightly in pencil for a count of 1-2-3 and then look at the shapes and see what they suggest to you. Then in pen,draw over the shape,and add to it. This will help alleviate the WhuhTuhDruh symptoms of stupification and apathy. And I would also remind them that what they are doing is Exploring, don't take it seriously, have fun,and discover what you can do.

Drawing is surprisingly high Iq similar to programming. You break down problems into smaller pieces making sure you understand what is required. In this case, you want to draw lineart but it looks like shit, how do you make it better? Then you realize you have to go deeper and break them down into even more parts so small you doubt you will even like drawing.
>appeal
>thick versus thin
>perspective
>form
>confident lines
>anatomy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6481616
Invest in some good quality drawing pads,and one pad of Bristol board. And,for now,black ballpoint pens,and a pencil.

Take the pad,and for a count of 1-2-3,scribble lightly with the pencil. Now see what the random shapes suggest to you. If this squiggle looks like a face use the pen to highlight those marks,and add details of your own. Feel free to draw upside down if the random shapes look promising. And,importantly, know that this is a way to awaken your imagination, and don't be disappointed with your first outings into art,even trying is to be applauded.
