I long trascended fear and anxiety.

Tough the techniques that would fix your personalities permanently take too long to explain and apply, you can default to the Mind Trick, of which I should publish an article one of these days.

It's simple and it's something that everyone is familiar with, though nobody but me appears to have understood its nature.

Ever learned to ignore tickles? Stop shivering from cold? Stop sneezing?
It's all one single state of mind, and if you engage in it you're basically choking off some brain processes temporarily for so long as you maintain it.

Why am I mentioning this? Because another effect is that you cannot feel emotions in that state.

I tested many times, and I can guarantee it. If you also have the ability to trigger any emotion at will, you can also try and come to the same conclusion. They're mutually exclusive.
So whenever you start feeling panic attacks or other unnecessary feelings that lead to loss of control, you now know what to do.

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465776
assistants tools usually take cpu cycles to keep calculating stuff even on idle, this may cause lag on bigger projects, also the farther the vanishing points the more resource it may use...

Using a image template (raster level) there is no thinking involve, so less prone in lagging another benefit is that as the template is just another layer I can apply all the functions available to layers (blending modes, stacking order, masking, etc.) I can't imagine making something like a comic strip in which every panel may have a different vanishing points from each other with assistants tools.
Ended up using this templates, https://www.davidrevoy.com/article814/perspective-grids-for-comics-in-krita
but I think I will make an 8k version.

Did I make myself understood?, I'm mentally drained kek

>>6467614
Done, yes, it is chalk from csp. From a quick test on krita it can be replicated using "chalk details" brush and playing around with pattern strength. For some reason this brush is much easier to give a seamless continuation using multiple overlapping strokes while having a nice line weight, probably because of the coarseness of the pattern.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465902
I think you should trace real people and anime characters, and get a feel for the curves, anatomy and how they are normally shaped.
You have some idea on what to do, but you may over exxagerate some stuff to a point thing it may look wrong, tracing should help bring it back to normal levels.
The word tracing may sound icky, but it helped for me and made me see what i got wrong despite figure drawing and study constantly, tracing just made it click.

If it helps, make some notes; i made the hp bone too sharp, my toes have too much definition, my shoulders are not as slender. Do stuff like that and you'll get afeel for how it's meant to be.

pen size = max(resolution dimension)*0.003
E.g. for a 2500x3500 canvas
3500*0.003 = 10.5 pen size and with small variable size.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6469437
you are drawing symbols. in other words, you are putting flat stickers of eyes and mouth on a template when you're supposed to draw things with volume and perspective in mind
for example, in a front shot, the eyes and mouth don't curve upward like that, they curve toward the face because they protrude off of it. you drew it as if you were looking from above although still wrong
my personal advice whould be to look into the planes of the face and features so you know how to apply perspective to them. believe it or not, although the average anime face looks fairly simple it still relies on understanding the structure of a real face to make it look cute

>>6474370
Keep the skin tone simple first, just work with 4.
1. Select the base flesh tone and fill body.
2. Select a lighter tone for highlights over softly.
3. Select a deeper tone for shadow areas, again softly apply.
4 Select a midway tone between the shadow and base tone to blend all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476430

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476412

You need to be able to recognize "values" in a painting. This is the base of your painting, the building blocks, the sauce on the pizza. Colors are toppings, decoration, sprinkles of accent and emotion - but the base values need to be there.

Check out Airi Pan's Fool Proof Concept Art course. She explains it rather well in the first couple of videos, but it's better that you practice it 'cause it's kinda hard to wrap your head around.

If I had to summarize it, I'd say that you need to be able to identify large shapes in your painting and separate them into something comprehensible and appealing. One good practice exercise is to take a screenshot from a movie, turn it into grayscale, squint your eyes and try to identify the shapes using only three values (black, white and gray). Colors come after - shape language is more important. Some of the real pros forego the value construction altogether - but that's because they're pros and know it all by heart already, so they start with color straight away.

>>6478111
Work smarter.
Hire or befriend a 3rd worlder to do it for you for free.
Learn software like Live2D or Spine2D where you only really need to draw a character once, with a few toggle expressions or whatever.
Learn 3D, and just make a 3d model, pose it in various ways, make renders, turn to 2D with a paintover, many games have used this technique.
Be efficient and just not have fluidly animated faggotry. You aren't a one man vanillaware, or even something like Hollow Knight where they had a dedicated artist actually spend all those hours doing the grindwork you say you hate so much. Get away with simpler shit, single images without animation, or only some simple bobbing/flinching, say it's part of the art style. VNs, TCGs, even shit like the older Fire Emblems get away with barely any animation.
Study retro games, look up sprite sheets, you'll be surprised at how few images they use, and how many of them are barely edited from each other and reused for multiple situations.

And out of curiosity what kind of game are you even trying to make? Like if it's a platformer, you can streamline a lot with the above tips and shortcuts, but if you want to make a full on Street Fighter clone solo, you are basically fucked.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6478212
The only way is what I mentioned then. If you want very detailed HD sprites, and don't wanna take forever nor spend a fortune hiring talent, is to cut back on animations. Work smart, adapt your ideas to a medium that will let you get away with shortcuts.
Visual novels.
TCGs.
Something like Paper Mario, where all characters are paper cut-outs and the animations are intentionally only a couple frames + some programmed stretched and squashing to give them life.
Another example of Stylistic shortcuts can be seen in Vanillaware's 13 sentinels, in the gameplay portions. They use super simple 3D models, and only HD high quality sprites and animations for the unit portraits and close ups of their attacks.
Fire Emblem/Advance Wars also worked like this, overworld units are like 2-3 frames only, even most of the animation attacks are only a couple keyframes, then they went all-in for the special attacks.
Another idea could be to do what games like Rayman, Drawn to Life, or the NDS Spore game did, where the body parts are straight up separate objects mostly moved around for animation rather than individually drawn animations. A lot of early 3D era games also worked in chunks, like you can see on games like Ocarina of Time that everyone's arms and legs are separate sausages clipping into each other rather than fully animated meshes.
Go for one of those shortcuts, and if need be, incorporate it into the art style and concept of the game. Make everyone be a puppet, or papercraft doll.
One last example of a clever shortcut: Return of the Obra Dinn. Guy learned 3D modeling from scratch, made some very simple and butt ugly models, but was smart to kinda cover them with stylistic filters so it's not too noticeable, and also made the smart call of making every scene be frozen in time, with the only real animation work needed done on the first person hand animations.

>>6478260
You have to plan the actual poses, designs and such to be easy to animate.
You can use things like tracing to build up the roughs enough for testing your gameplay, hitboxes,etc and add additional work over the roughs to finish them later.

The simple fact is that the shortcuts you want already exist - rigging, tracing, copy-pasting, simplification, tweening, reusing assets in ways the player/viewer doesn't notice, and so on. You just have to design the project to meet a standard if you don't want to spend the rest of your life doing this, and apply them appropriately.

Have two characters with the same body type? At some point you may need them to wear a similar outfit (naked, disguises, armor, etc.) Simply copypaste the body and reuse the same outfits but fix the body language.

Basically, go learn how to animate efficiently and effectively because most spritework consists of short animations/loops off the same starting/ending points.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Growing your platform as an artist
posts.com:
What do you do to grow your platform as an artist that wants a large audience?
Do you just post your flavor of the month fanart and let it speak for itself while praying to the algorithm gods?
Or do you create extra content to boost your engagement and reach?
I've been thinking of tapping into video platforms like TikTok but have yet to come up with interesting concepts that isn't just a drawing timelapse + music.
I hate the idea of becoming a content creator but what other choice do you have when simply posting your art doesn't bring any results?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Post good art, consistently. This is the hardest part for people. If your art isn't good - not "lowest common denominator", niche art is fine - and if you don't post enough, you fucking die.

For some platforms this means daily. For others it means between alternating days and 3 times a week.

Don't use it like a personal blog. If you shill paid stuff, make it "there but nonintrusive." Interact with people so you have a personality, and they get that parasocial dopamine hit but don't overdo it.

Don't watermark your stuff to all hell, and use a LEGIBLE, non-intrusive signature so people can find you - reverse image searches don't hit every site. No scribbles.

Post your art in appropriate places, preferably anonymously. Don't link or say anything, just share. If sauce is asked, provide it.
After you get enough traction, if you decide to open some kind of subscription service - leak it to kemono/ehentai/etc.

An artist's value is defined by how often his shit gets reposted. The more people who see your art, the more likely some will want to follow. The more who follow, the more who will want to interact, and the more who interact, the more who will be willing to pay you.
A lot of artists get a portion of this wrong and focus only on followers/watchers as a raw number, but if your art is shared without a lot of extra context then the people who go through the effort to find it are likely going to be "quality followers" rather than "inactive followers." The total follower count only matters in that a portion of that is going to be quality followers.

Note that SOME artists with good enough art (often in a broad enough niche) can compensate for failing in other areas. I have seen artists who shitpost and do the "posting screenshots and food photos" thing on their social media or are constantly blabbering in their journals on galleries, but the art is good enough to enough people that it compensates for it.
Still, if they didn't do that shit they'd be WAY bigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472190
I should also stress that "interacting with people" means the people who are interacting with YOU. Limit it to things "about your art." Thank people if they like it (thank each person who leaves a comment until you're popular enough that it becomes too much.) If using twitter or posting in an art discord or something, don't post reaction images as that disrupts peoples' ability to find your art using ctrl+f "from:anonshithead in:pyw has:image" or the media tab.

If you DO want to use reaction images, draw them. Each time. Draw a new one. This limits how many you show, as well as forcing you to practice more. It also, again, does that dopamine hit of "OHMYGODMYFAVORITEARTISTDREWAREACTIONJUSTFORME" to the followers and encourages more interactions. Just make sure the people who you reply to with it are at least semi-random.

>>6471012

I make 95K a year doing storyboards in the US.

You have to stay within the confines of the script, there are times when you can make some changes but you have to pitch it to your superiors so it goes you > director > supervising director > showrunner/execs. If your change makes it all the way through that multiple times it probably will stay in through the final.

We do a lot of previs here in the US so shot composition, and fight choreography. but it depends. A lot of board artists in the US like to do almost key animation because there isn't a huge budget for retake animation.

I will say that you don't HAVE to be a super good draftsman to be a great board artist. But if you can combine good drawing skills with a rudimentary level of knowledge of animation and shot composition you will never be out of a job for more than months at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6471069
do you have a lot of free time outside of work to make comics / personal projects? How busy are you when you are actually in the office? (like, how reasonable are the deadlines?)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471081

Yes and No.

Storyboarding is not a 40-hour-a-week job in the sense that. It requires such a command of so many different skills some of which have nothing to do with drawing; Time Management, Shot Comp, Animation, and Draftsmanship hell if your gonna make your storyboards you need to have editing know-how. So realistically you're gonna be working 50-70 hour weeks.

But there's a catch. A good one I might add. My schedule is roughly 10-11 weeks per episode. We turn things in and have to wait a week or two for notes and this process happens about 3 times after that 11-week deadline. So sometimes we are sitting on our hands or helping other teams on their episodes.

So if you make sure to hone your time management skills you can have a bunch of free time. But when we are working it's intense, but it's kind of made up for on the back end.

It's okay man, I lurk here from time to time but I only answer questions that I view as sincere. So don't worry about it.

I don't feel trapped at all, storyboarding exposes you to so much that when you're doing it you can't help but improve. I'm only a few years in but I know people that maintain a comic and board. The thing is that there are a lot of opportunities to move up (some people get in through nepotism, but not all), and with moving up comes a significant pay bump. I'm talking about being a Director (120-195K a year), but it also comes with more responsibilities and that means those 50+ hour weeks just went to 80+ hour weeks and on top of that YOU are responsible for how the animatic turns out, so more stress too.

I know people who just hit that 10-year mark, they are all mostly directors by then, and if they aren't they are just board artists that are paid well because they want to protect their time because they want to do what you wanna do. It's a balancing act, no one can tell you what to do. But the only way you'll know is if you commit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473076

I started as a revisionist, I didn't finish school. I got more and more opportunities as time went on. Like I said above, there's no correct answer besides actual boarding. I know it's kind of a meme but everyone's path is different and you will never know until you commit to a path of action. I'll say this about portfolios, everyone says you should have 2-3 different pieces with action and drama, etc. But that's not necessarily true. I got hired off of a few action poses and one board. So In my experience, I would say focus on making boards and composition but also focus on life drawing and figure drawing, I mean actually sit down and work through the phases, lay in, contour, values, and finishing. A few hours a day thumbnailing for boards, and a few hours a day life drawing will take you insanely far. By the time you get around to finishing a board you will be better than you were. And on top of that if you always thumbnailing you will have a bunch of thumbs that you can draw upon to make into full boards in the future if you want to. it's a win-win. Also, learn Storyboard Pro as well as you can in school if you have access to it.

/co/ makes it sound like the entire industry beneath the corporate level requires you to not only hold whatever "current thing" left wing values are the new hotness, but also to demonstrate or signal that you're an ally in some way. But the one thing that keeps me from trying to get into animation is that I don't want to be forced to put on an act and celebrate each and every left wing position just for my peers, lest I be ostracized or scapegoated or whatever else. I would love to just keep my mouth shut and draw, but the online left wing world suggests that silence is in itself some admission of being an adversary. And if I were ever asked a loaded question I wouldn't want to have my reputation quietly tarnished just because I answered neutrally instead of being unequivocally supportive.
I'm not convinced that working in American animation can be separated from the current state of politics. And if that's the case I'll stick to blue collar trade work.

I know boarding and animating isn't the place to let individual creativity shine, but it still must be frustrating to know you can't say or do this or that because it wouldn't align with whatever the workplace climate is. I know animators even decades ago would feel stifled by the basic S&P of network programming. This seems like it'd be S&P on steroids.
>Just don't put your foot in your mouth
I'm not the type to talk or reveal anything about myself in general. But I know that among young, political leaning types they always want to small talk about current events or the latest outrage, looking to find some kind of solidarity when you nod and agree and gasp. I don't want to do some kind of pantomime every day with politics I disagree with, be they right or left. But it appears so deeply ingrained in animator/entertainment culture like an expectation.

Sorry, forgot about this thread.
>Do I have to say I'm a black trans disabled lesbian in order to get interviews? Will I ever get hired if I'm a straight white male?
They're gonna find out whether you're white or not if you're looking for full-time positions anyways, even if remote. As a leaf, my country is brainwashed on diversity shit, but they still definitely do hire straight white males because they get the job done.

A heads up to anyone applying for jobs: you'll need to be prepared for some level of an interview and an art test. On top of a phone interview, I also had to do in-person interview or a Zoom/Google Meets interview. About 2 or sometimes 3 rounds of them. If you get more than 1 interview, it's a good chance they really liked you. Shit is tiring but easy as fuck to pass as long as you don't act like an asshole or someone who sniffs their own farts. Always ask questions at the end of the interview.

The art test is usually to see if you can match their in-house style and to see if you were bluffing in your portfolio.

Try looking into your local job listings and make a LinkedIn account to apply to more listings found in your country/city. You may have to move countries or cities if you live in bumfuck nowhere though.

This thread gave me all I needed to know about this board. It's full of people with no talent or abstractist thinking who spend years and years trying to fit into being an artist, Or Illustrator or anything. They work hard or work for a long time to become this thing they want to be however because of this they become cynical, jaded, Do they truly love it? posts.name: Anonymous

>>6474936
It's just part of a small farewell present for a tank commander, commanding a mine flail called 'Keiler', which is German for male wild boar. He is also a hunter and comes from an area renowned for its woods and hills which were also painted by Casper David Friedrich a lot. I told the AI to create the painting in CDF's style for which the painting is much too bright and not detailed enough but I was still relatively satisfied with the result. It was definitely the best result of at least a dozen generations.

The canvas will probably end up hanging in his new office. Adding structure to it seemed like an easy way to fool most people who don't know anything about painting and only visit his office briefly into thinking this was actually painted by hand. I feel like I would be somewhat impressed to see something like this hanging in someone's office in my line of work.

People usually don't put too much effort or money into presents like these but I feel like it's more original than a group photo or a piece of shrapnel signed by the whole platoon. In the end it will have cost me around 40 euros and maybe 3 hours of work which seems reasonable.

>>6474985

>>6475030
Why don't you commission an actual fucking oil painting of this image, having the artist change it in any way you desire, maybe even to the point where it doesn't look like soulless twitter funko pop shit? ANY (male) art student in your area is going to be able to make something like this except better, for $3-400 easily, eagerly.
This image will always look digital, no matter what you do to it, even assuming a perfect print, which there won't be, because it's AI-generated sRGB. You also misunderstand how varnish works. Varnish settles. The reason paintings are bumpy is because of the paint, not the varnish. A brush will add "grain" to it, maybe, but it will still settle onto the even surface of the print in an even way, unless you flash cure it with UV or something, and even then, there won't be enough varnish. You can't just dump a centimeter thick layer on it, it will never cure.

I'm assuming these are all from same person yeah?
I'd suggest more decisive lines, try to visualize what you want to put down before you do. Looks like you're familiar with drawthrough method obviously, but yeah there is some inconsistencies in the perspective, but the drawings major issue is the hairy lines, also once you have that down don't get lost in the details, make sure it still reads as the object intended from a distance. You could also try drawing some mechanical objects in a 3 point perspective and see how you do. Hope that helps although You've probably heard similar advice before

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458574
I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

>>6480334
It's funny to think that Western art - primarily Disney's Snow White - inspired Ultraboy, who then inspired the proto anime art style of the seventies, which was deconstructed by the rough and tumble style eighties anime is known for, which continued down the pipeline of cleaning up and refining until it became what we know today.

In a manner of speaking, Pregolden-age Western art created twenty first century Western art, in the most roundabout way possible.

Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. >>6464068
Read how stable diffusion actually works. It basically trains the algorithm to denoise a generated noisy image over a number of iterations to produce an image (along with whatever NLP algorithm is used to interpret the initial prompt). Also it's unsupervised learning, meaning there is no real validation afterwards, it just returns after running.

What it means is that if the training images already have some proc generated watermark all over it, generated in a way that it couldn't easily be removed by existing watermark removal tools, than any generated images of that artist's artstyle (ie. generate xyz in the style of so and so) would try to include those watermarks as well and it would make it really obvious that it was AI generated because they'd likely be fucked up looking in ways a human could easily determine (ie. similar to how SD has no concept of how many fingers a hand has and constantly generates fucked up looking ones)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464025
Retrained how?
Let me put it this way
1. Artist A posts a lot of public art, but all there art includes some watermark repeated, but altered in some semi random way based on a seed/key that only they have

2. This art is scraped and used as a training dataset for an art generation AI

3. Someone only enters the prompt "I want this image in artist A's style" and the AI creates an image

Now, because all of the artists images included that watermarking, the AI will naturally try to include something similar to it, but without knowing that initial seed/key the original artist will have an easy way of proving that this is a generated version, not authentic.

And even if someone altered the prompt to not include the watermark, and it manages to generates something that looks remotely convincing (although it's unclear if it could or how well it would look) given that all of the publicly available images include them, that's also a giveaway

Make sense

It's not worth worrying about. Feel better that some shithead SEAmonkey or pajeet felt your art was good enough to waste time saving, editing, re-saving, and uploading the modified version. And if people go "WOW WHO DID THIS I LOVE IT??" they'll likely get an answer if your stuff is publicly reverse-image searchable (basically on dA, pixiv, FA, Artstation, etc. as twitter and insta don't get indexed reliably.)

Besides that, it's far more likely that people just reup without cropping or anything. Having people mod your stuff is a sign you're starting to make it!

>>6477386
This is bad because it increases the likelihood that people will miss it, and if someone REALLY wants to remove your sig then they can still do so.
If you insist on trying to make it as "permanent" as possible, a way to do it is to put a cleanly-readable sig over something that's a bitch to smooth out, like on the border of 2 gradients or crossing past errant strands of hair.
The more out-of-the-way it is the worse you're making it, because smearing it with not-quite-right colors can be more easily passed off. Making it have a feathered border can also make this worse to remove.

But this is a big pain in the ass vs a bar at the top or bottom of the image (reminiscent of one part of a letterbox) that contains your info and probably the date or something too.

Disney animator Glen Keane claims to have aphantasia. Do you think he, and other artists like him, have true aphantasia? I can certainly imagine that purely observational artists could draw well with aphantasia (in fact I could even see the lack of distraction from mental images to be helpful in this pursuit), but I don't quite get how an artist with true aphantasia could even begin a drawing from imagination. I saw him say that he starts with scribbles and refines from there, but starting with a rough gesture and refining is common practice even for artists who can see images in their mind, and I'd think a true lack of mental imaging would prohibit the placement of even a comprehensible gestural sketch from imagination.

tl;dr Do creative artists with aphantasia truly exist, or are they just full of shit/don't actually have thoughts devoid of imagery?

Hello, I hope I am not being obnoxious talking about my girlfriend again. But she has true Aphantasia (Cannot see any kind of visual memories in her mind at all).
However, she began drawing around 3 weeks ago and I am training her using a similar path to what Krenz proposes.
So far, I am seeing her progress faster than i did (I stand in stark contrast, as I am I can visualize very well).
Things I've noticed she seems naturally better at.
1.Organizing her process, from the steps on going from sketch to coloring to layer organization
2. She seems to have a better hand to eye coordination, has a lot of patience and works well.
3. Takes a lot more care in detailing, fishing, making something presentable
4. She is able to notice details in things that often go over me, as I am often lost in thought, that comes both for observation and general media consumption

I am curious to see her progress, and I'll likely post more about how effective the training is for anyone else with Aphantasia or who might simply be curious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475582
Most of us are just executing a procedure here and there trying to bend it toward "what looks good" with trial and error. Sometimes we have a strong idea and try to bend it toward that, but that makes the process harder.

I don't have aphantasia, but I don't have strong visualization abilities, and making visualizations isn't part of my or most other artists process.

I think you have some idealized notion that artists "see something in their mind" and mentally project it onto a page and trace. I'd be surprised if even one human artist on the whole planet does that.

There are artist that *do* have visualization as part of their process, like the late Kim Jung Gi, but another part of the process was building a library of processes by doing drawings from reference of lots of different things.

Draftsman, animators and painters from imagination don't have psychic powers. They just work harder than you and know more than you.

I do see flashes when tired and shortly before going to sleep. for me that's working alright. but in the waking state I just see black when closing my eyes, I just see black when thinking of a person or an object. as another anon said here, drawing for me is like starting out on a blank space, knowing what do to in theory, but going in completely blind, building up with each stroke, trial and error, not knowing where the actual drawing goes on paper.

>>6478748
I can close my eyes and mentally walk through places I've been to, look at objects, pick them up, turn them around, etc. No, it isn't the same as actually seeing them with your eyes, and the details can get muddled when really trying to examine things (like I can't just look at a page of a book and read the words later or look at an image of something and recreate it later, it still works based on some amount of memorization, and the more I've looked at or interacted with something the better i can manipulate it in my mind). If I have a somewhat clear idea in mind, I can close my eyes and gesture draw over the image in my mind's eye on paper to get the start to a drawing.
I'd say that if you can draw something from imagination, you probably don't actually have aphantasia.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475697
I think that's probably the case with the majority of people who "have" aphantasia.
The only people I know who were told by a doctor that they either have it, or most likely have it, also have legitimate brain damage from drug abuse.
I don't doubt that some portion of the average population with functioning brains have it, but I think a decent sample of them probably just didn't read enough as kids or something and never developed much of an imagination. Even artists who can visualize stuff still need to actively work on their visual library and learn how to rotate forms in their head. It's a skill you have to develop like anything else, and like every other skill (especially the artistic ones), most people simply do not ever have a need to learn or hone it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472850
Da Vinci's treatise on painting?
https://www.gutenberg.org/files/46915/46915-h/46915-h.htm

Painting back then was in its infancy; its teaching is much more "recipe-based" and less systematic than it is today ("if you want to paint that kind of stuff, then do this and that"; Cennini is a great example of it).

For instance, back then, color wasn't understood as hue/value/saturation. Such systems aren't perfect, but they are incredibly useful to handle colors. My point is, even if you aim at studying ancient techniques, don't neglect modern refinements.

Is Krita as good as Photoshop for digital painting?
Got a new computer, old photoshop won't work on it, can't be bothered to pirate new photoshop, and just want to paint. Will the transition be easy?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Free software sucks. Because the team aren't paid to give a crap about cheapiefaggots using it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Are you good enough at digital art to where the benefits of photoshop over krita are worth having to run windows?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6478721
It's free, download it and try it. Krita is meant to be used in tandem with GIMP though. They don't step on each others' toes very much.

>Use GIMP for scanning/editing, as well as text
>Use Krita for painting/coloring/drawing

Photoshop has better filters, direct access to sold/shared brushes from various professionals, photo-editing tools built in, and many other things because Adobe is huge.
But krita still has over 20 years of well-funded development so it's not shitty like paint.net is. Still, because it was first released in 2005 after like 7 years of work, it does some things "weirdly."

Everything is blending layers. Your brush can have a blending layer applied to it as well which changes how it behaves in tandem with the layer you are using. The way the brushes work is completely different from other programs and is too much to explain.
There's a button to toggle eraser on/off for the brush you're using. You can hotkey it to swap tools to an "eraser brush" if you want though.

In fact you can hotkey pretty much anything, the amount of options are massive including mostly-useless ones like being able to hotkey opening the "report a bug" window.

In general though, krita expects you to either explore the program in depth to learn it, or to RTFM. It has a learning curve and you will be shit coming from any other program until you get comfy with it.

But once you do, you will be free.

Krita's text editor is shit though, worst part about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
it's good enough, in some ways it's better in other ways it's worse. if someone thinks krita is holding you back, it's a skill issue not a software issue.
it has weird quirks because open source devs have to do things differently for some reason. at least there are settings or plugins you can use to change it to how you like.
david revoy has decent videos and brushes.
https://www.youtube.com/@DavidRevoy/videos

lots of brushes on the forums too.
https://krita-artists.org/c/resources/brushes-and-bundles/32

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6478671

Most of what you do is work for companies - their web pages, their advertising material, parts of their projects, etc.

The rest of this post is if you're doing work for individuals.

Live drawing/painting at flea markets and faires along with trucking along your originals to both sell and advertise your work.

Merch like bookmarks, postcards, phone cases, posters and prints and the like also help out

Some people advertise their work in game/comic stores or the equivalent online, doing things like D&D character portraits and tokens or MTG Card alterations.

Fanart done in unique ways is also good - the above ideas but specifically where you're making the art based on inspirational quotes or memorable moments from anime/games/fillms/etc is huge. There's a lot of niche markets there. It's of dubious legality so you might get a C&D if you bother the wrong company with your fanart though.

In general it's harder without being hired for a project or company because as a SFW artist you aren't meeting much of a need in individual people beyond their desire to have a pretty decoration or a gift for someone. The people who want to commission said decorations and gifts are even fewer and farther between.

procreate is garbage pushed to trend chasing normalfags
it used to be ok, but it’s been shit since 4.0 with bugs out the ass, retarded interface for the new features like adjustments which also can’t be layers and have retarded meme “alternatives” to, lacks basic fucking shit like sampling lower layers, and a dysfunctional brush engine that made some of the best old brushes behave like shit
like sadie’s (from the op) best sketching brushes no longer work because THE FUCKING TILT HAS BEEN BUGGED FOR 3 FUCKING YEARS AND PRODUCES ERATIC NONSENSE ON THE FUCKING DOWNSTROKE with size compression on even their own default brushes do it, they just hide it with a noisy stamp and texture, pic fucking related

for the ipad, the best apps are
CSP (lol sub)
Artstudio Pro (basically photoshop minus the high level photo editing)
Infinite Painter (low layer ceiling, even lower than procreate, also on android but idk if it’s the same)
Paintstorm Pro (fucking amazing brush engine, but drains battery like an absolute bitch)
Realistic Paint Studio (same devs and engine as paintstorm, also a bitch on the battery, but limited and tailored for a more sketchbook experience to the point they didn’t even let you color pick from a ref before the normalfags started whining)
Affinity Photo (basically photoshop with a lot of the high level editing, but kinda shit to draw/paint in because of shitty input interpretation, like brushes start as if you pressed hard for one stamp, then switch to what you actually did, but haven’t touched it in a long while)
Adobe Fresco (was barebones but maturing rapidly, haven’t touched it in a while, lacked basic shit and went out of its way to not copy every other app, resulting in a shitty basic UI)

CSP and ASP are the best hands down, ASP takes all PS brushes (except live/3d brushes), both abr and tpl, both are very productive without a keyboard and have full key customisation, I like ASP better

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6478206
You're the one who knows the answer to that.
I've read Loomis and Right Side of the Brain twice now, and both times I got bounced back when I pointed out the content gap both books have between "draw the outline of an owl" and "draw the rest of the owl".
Loomis is without doubt a lot of help and fun when you've caught up, but I get bucked off after the first few faces because he starts assuming you're already past symbol drawing and most importantly that you know enough to correct your own mistakes.
Right Side is brilliant as a psychological/neurological work, but like Loomis the author assumes and assures too much - case in point, the Picasso exercise you're told you'll be amazed at (I noticed a faint difference while drawing and wanted to build on that, but the book had long run off on its own).

>>6478315
Very beg, but you have nice line art and ok grasp of volume.
Your weakest parts however, I'd say are proportions and gesture, work on those, as well as some master study tips.
For example, look at how curved her spine is, her entire body is arched in a C shape, yours is very stiff and straight, gesture will fix that. Also learn about master copy concepts like midpoints, level/plumb lines, negative space, and other such techniques, your head is in the completely wrong angle, the arm isn't foreshorted enough, and your legs are too long, all these are fixable with the proper copy techniques.

>>6478631
In my experience, I tried to learn to draw an accurate pelvis from imagination for several months. I even started a whole general about it, the /skeleton/ general, but even after 3 months of drawing from the 3d model, I couldn't make it work.

Fast forward, I bought a plastic pelvis model from amazon, and within a couple days, I got it. All the information that was too clumsy to get in the 3d model, I could immediately feel and touch with my fingers. All the angles, thicknesses, and curvature was right there.

You don't need a physical model for every bode, you just need it for the difficult bones, like the pelvis and skull. Probably the hands and feet bone too

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6478704
>Learning is at least a three- step process: initial encoding of
information is held in short- term working memory before being consolidated into a cohesive representation of knowledge in long- term memory. Consolidation reorganizes and stabilizes memory traces, gives them meaning, and makes connections to past experiences and to other knowledge already stored in long- term memory. Retrieval updates learning and enables you to apply it when you need it.
>Learning always builds on a store of prior knowledge. We
interpret and remember events by building connections to
what we already know. Long- term memory capacity is virtually limitless: the more
you know, the more possible connections you have for adding
new knowledge.
>Because of the vast capacity of long- term memory, having
the ability to locate and recall what you know when you need
it is key; your facility for calling up what you know depends
on the repeated use of the information (to keep retrieval routes
strong) and on your establishing powerful retrieval cues that
can reactivate the memories.

The "everyday" part is far more important in "x time everyday"

First mistake is going straight to digital. If you don't have the muscle memory and hand-eye coordination to draw clean lines and shapes on paper digital is going to fuck you in the ass.

Having the drive to fix your mistakes is something that comes not from expertise but from an intrinsic desire to do better. Your issue is not that you do not know how to draw, but that you seem to not know how to learn something new.

Just start drawing. Copy and study art that seems well made to you. There are lots of names dropped on this board. Get curious and google one of those names, see if the art interests you. If it doesn't google another name, and see how that goes.

We are just anons, we are not trained in pedagogy. Everyone's learning journey will be different, and none of us have the understanding of art education that is necessary to hold your hand and walk you through your journey. All we can do is point you towards resources we have found helpful, and provide tips and critique when we feel qualified.

Just draw and have fun, anon. Don't sweat it so much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479761
Seems pretty good, you kept the values simple and under control. I would reassess the shadow shapes on the upper chest, between the top of the breasts and clavicle, the shadows don't quite make sense. You could push the contrast more, but that depends on how hard or soft the light of the environment is supposed to be. You don't have to do the warm light/cool shadows thing, it's a stylistic rule of thumb that generally works but it doesn't have to be heavy handed, like in >>6479772 you posted, those shadows are cool, just very subtle. Cool just means "tending towards blue" but not necessarily blue, same with warm and red, so as long as the average shadow is closer to blue on the color wheel than your average light, the shadows will be "cool".

>>6479786
However much you need :^). I always use at least a little bit to compensate for shitty tablet, but I wouldn't use so much that the cursor moves slower than you actually draw.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479791
Pen on paper are your friends.

Drawing digitally is fun, but to work on improving it is best to practice traditionally to build hand-eye coordination and muscle memory.

You understand how perspective works in theory, but haven't practiced enough in freehand mode.
Stop making full pieces for a while and just doodle random crap with ballpoint (~1px AA non-pressure brush, if digital) at least 2 hours everyday for a couple months. Anime girls, robots, weapons, penises, vehicles, anything as long as you have a rough 3D model of it in your head. Don't spend more than 30 minutes on a single object.

If you absolutely need some handholdy course with assignments then look for art-wod.

posts.sub: Schizo take on social media feedback
posts.com:
So I just post stuff I've occasionally drawn on insta for the sake of it - who knows maybe it hits the right spot for someone else. I also follow a few people whose style and art I really like and sometimes express it through an appreciative comment, a share and sometimes join their art contests. Couple of them are big-ish i.e. 10k+ follows or something and they seemed to welcome this feedback to the point where they follow me back, "like" my work and sometimes we have a chat about the community and art or whatever. All cool. Nice.

The issue begins when I start getting praise comments/feedback from them. Of course feedback is nice, sure. Everyone likes getting that nice uplifting comment. But I really value genuine feedback.

Recently I've come to think the positive feedback/messages I get from those artists are just forced back scratching with no value. I may have no following and thus they probably try to support, but this support sounds fake to the point where it feels condescending.

Like, you don't give a shit about my art, why pretend? I don't draw things you care about. I'm no striving artist. I'm just an average joe pinup animeshit artist to pass my time.

I guess you want to get it off your chest that you've "now supported me back" since I went up your ass, but now it has an opposite effect. I don't believe anything they say anymore. It instead hurts because in the beginning I thought shit was genuine and I had actual artists liking my work. I gave up and disabled comments/shares. I'd rather get nothing over bs.

So did I hit a shit community corner where children are indoctrinated to hugbox or is this the norm I'm too stupid to understand?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Study light/shadow, do the usual meme with shading balls and shit, learn anatomy so you know which parts of the body are shaded when the light hits from a certain direction, paint skin hit by light color A, skin in shadow color B, use soft edge brush to blend the transition.
For shit like the dress and its folds as well as the back jewelry, same deal. Do a lot of cloth and material studies so you know which materials will have softer or rougher shadows, and how to light cloth folds.

>but that wasted time definitely won't make you worse at it.
It's a simple case of use it or lose it. Putting dozens of hours into a painting (as one does) is as helpful for your other fundamentals as laying in bed doing nothing at all. I'm not saying that rendering magically makes you bad, just that spending 12 hours on a painting is as good for your draftsmanship as not doing any art at all. It's nearly the same as if you spent your day playing video games or jacking off. People who got into art young don't have that problem because it's all second nature to them anyway, they can only go forward because those neural pathways that relate to art are incredibly strong.

This is very easy to understand if you have any skill you acquired as a child. For me it's the violin. I can play very very well and even if I go long periods without practicing I can pick up where I left off. I literally cannot forget how to play well, unless of course I get a stroke or something. Also the same with English (I'm ESL in a third world shithole), I always mogged everyone in all my English classes because I learned English as a kid, no matter how hard everyone else tried I would just be better without having to put in any effort. With art, however, I'm that kid who tries super hard to speak English and gets mogged by others who just had the opportunity to learn when their XP multiplier was at its highest.

I had this realization recently, there are things that I learned as a child that I just am good at. Then there's drawing which I got into at 21 (23 now) and its impossibly difficult to learn.

I only bother with Patreon and Gumroad so

You have to skirt around Patreon's rules because the banks cucked them which means you're getting cucked too.
Also set up your patreon so that you're charging Patrons the moment they sign up a pledge. You'll end up getting a couple of people who will hop between different pledges so they can collect whatever you have and then leave so make that change in how you charge your Patrons first before anything else because Patreon for whatever reason doesn't have that set as the default
Cropping your images also helps with this but it also helps keep Patreon itself off your back. Because of Banks cucking them Patreon now has rules about what you can and cannot post on their site, so crop out the really bad stuff and only post those on your Discord instead

For Gumroad all I can say is that it's good passive income so long as you're actively advertising that you have one with stuff to sell on it. It doesn't have to be big things like long comics, some doodles and images with alts work too as well

Don't be discouraged when people inevitably leak your work. Sometimes you'll gain a few new followers who like it and will want to support you

... i am sorry for your loss.

you should have been less ambitious with those pose and instead stick to what you know. no-ref means you can't go crazy unless you've learned it before, you actually are supposed to stay in your comfort zone a bit more. eventually you can do even unpracticed stuff without ref if you do it often enough. the only other thing i can think of for advice is 2 things.
1: Go radically in the opposite direction. Avoid all meme advice completely, only do something if you yourself see that it works. repeat what usually works for you. None of the memes work right? You should know that better than anyone now. By not following memes, you are simply avoiding what usually doesn't work.

2: pay very close attention to if you're about to do something that usually doesn't work. If you catch yourself doing it, STOP, reorient, do anything else.
next, If you notice whenever you do x, it usually does come out nice, try doing it more. The real trick here is in developing your awareness, that you are constantly checking to see if you are doing something that leads you on a path that leads to a bad drawing, frustration, and whatever. Actually apply this, it is great for helping with stagnation, it's a bit of a natural corrector

>>6477558
>light and shadow
light being emitted from a light source tend to reflect and spread in bouncing rays, until they reach your eyes sensors.

Your eye genetics determine what colors and what intensity of values they can detect.
In practical terms light simply follows another vanishing point towards a light source, and you use perpective techniques to draw it properly.

>color harmonies
arragement of colors that has specific effects or uses.
By example, monochrome pallethes tend to have an unique mood compared to oposite or dual oposite color pallethes.

Such effect is related to the psychological effect each color has.
By example, a monochrome blue pallethe will have a melancholical effect, while one with yellow black and red will have an evil and dark effect.

Generally it follows a 60/30/10 proportion usually in most character designs.

>Shape design
Shape psychology relates to 3 basic shapes.
Cube = Reliable and hardworking.
Spiky = Dangerous and agressive.
Circle = Feminine and weak, cute also.

Shape design is basically designing your character to be a certain % of one of the 3 shapes, in most of it's shapes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6477362
I feel like people like OP is a lot more common than one might think. Somewhat technically competent but due to lacking a clear vision of WHAT exactly they want to do with said skills, they end up plateauing alongside their skills because I highly doubt you ACTUALLY "studied and grinded" that long and not achieve anything. If your goal was to simply draw good, then you'd have become someone like Kim Jung Gi that can draw entire pages with one stroke. Since that doesn't seem to be the case, you were absolutely not studying unless you thought of it as some sort of RPG where you slowly gained experience points then level up which is retarded. You need to be as specific as you can with what exactly you want.

In my friend's case, he wants to draw a manga/story and here's an example of one of his drawings. He has much, much more detailed ones and a million times better than me despite the fact that he claims that he wasn't doing too much of the raw grinding a lot of beginners do like making a million boxes. Easily high int. And in my case, I want to be competent enough to be able to make soulful art for a video game I want to make. Was symbol drawing just a few months ago and I barely even drew. Now I'm much more efficient because I can specifically say what exactly I need to be able to do to make said "game" because that in on itself is too vague. Backgrounds, main characters, interactable NPC, uninteractable NPCs... etc. All of those can be broken even further down like with character's clothes, what food they eat, how they talk, how their body looks relative to everyone, how they pee, how do they fuck and react to certain things? Stuff like that. Once I did that, not only was I able to discipline myself better to keep drawing, I'm able to bring more better results compared to when everything was just vague. I hope I'm making sense.

Ok, so your sketch is incredibly basic and hard to even see (idk why you chose light blue color on yellow paper), yet I assume you used it to jump straight to the detailed drawing? Yea no wonder it looks like shit, at your skill level you have to do it "step by step". Why? Because this allows you to spot and fix mistakes at every step rather than do all the work first, then go "oh shit, I did it wrong, guess I have no talent then". See pic related? You jumped straight from 1 to 4. Some people can get away with that but you clearly can't, so don't skip the in-between steps next time.

Also I agree with the other anons, drop the over-stylized anime style for a while, it's doing you more harm than good. You don't have to go full-realism, just try to get the proportions right. Also, try drawing a bunch of figures without clothes and hair to figure out what humans actually look like. It's not enough to just read a bunch of books about art, you actually have to WORK on your skill

Find some proportion diagrams, look at them, copy them, roughly sketch the diagrams from memory, check them. Keep it in mind when you start drawing figures from life or reference, and when you draw poses from imagination.
All that said, you can always use reference. Keep studying anatomy, perspective, proportion, etc as you draw, but don't think you need to be a master of everything before you finally start drawing what you want to draw; don't think you need to reach the magical point of "everything I draw is entirely from my mind" before you start producing the art you want to produce. Never be afraid to use references, especially with all the libraries of reference photos out there, pose dolls/software, your own body and camera, etc etc., but you'll find that the more you draw, the less you'll have to rely on references as starting points and the more you'll use them as helpers or checks.

>>6476045
Ugh. I honestly think you should ignore all these teachers who think you should be a human graphics card. Computers have had a baleful influence on art instruction, in that people look at wireframes and 3D models and think the goal is for you to be able to draw complex 3D constructions in violent perspective from any point of view. It's absurd. What's the point, anyway?
In most great figurative art of the past, perspective in the figures is not emphasized, because perspective entails distortion that, in depictions of the human figure, isn't pleasing to the eye. Art instruction books of the past tended to focus on the characteristic forms of the head, torso, limbs, etc. in repose and in action. You can learn this without turning everything into boxes and wireframes.
Yes, you should know the fundamentals of perspective (not difficult, read "Perspective Made Easy"). And yes, it is useful to draw cross-contours or think of cylinders and planes when foreshortening a limb, but turning this type of construction into a quasi-religion, as is being done here, is insane.
A useful and practical way of learning to draw, say, a thigh from the side view:
1. The attachment of the thigh to the trunk is higher in front than behind. So, too is the attachment of thigh to knee.
2. The front line is a gentle, convex curve with its peak closer to the top than the bottom, and inclined so the top is slightly forward in relation to the bottom. It runs from a little below the front pelvic point above, to just above the knee cap.
3. The back line is nearly straight from its start below the buttocks to its end just below the back of the knee. However, the upper two-thirds of this line bulges in a very subtle, convex curve.
And so on. Curved lines, straight lines and angles. If you can write the letter C, you can draw a curved line. Now think about the characteristics of the curve you are studying -- how it is angled, where it peaks, how gentle or violent the curvature.

Why is the top down learning approach significantly more often taught than the bottom up one?

I think there is something deeply wrong with how beginners are taught. As a child, I drew from children books and worked my way up to cartoons, comics and then photography. This seems to be the natural progression of art, we start with cave drawings and as we notice the complexities of reality we work our way up to oil paintings. Why is it then, that beginners are so often taught to draw from real life? In my humble opinion, this is completely overwhelming to a starter.

Think of it this way - virtually every other skill taught out there goes from simple to complex.

In a highly stialized drawing the value of a line and colour is greater, as beginners learn to draw they can learn to reapect each descission they make. Working their way up as natural progression goes.

They key word here is FROM. Realism is only hard if you're trying to conjure up imagery purely from your mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474581
This is kind of an open question but it seems most places start teaching with copies from the flat + life drawing. You're right that you need the training wheels first, but you also need to develop the ability to observe from life quickly because it will teach you how the 2d works you copy are "styled." You are consciously or unconsciously building a shape library in your head, so if you just copy 10,000 bad drawings, you're damaging your aesthetic progress. If you are a beg, this is made much worse by the fact that you don't really know what a good drawing is yet. Drawing from life doesn't have this last problem, and will always help you see, depict, and appreciate beauty directly, no matter your skill level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474581
>Why is the top down learning approach significantly more often taught than the bottom up one?
>(...)
>Why is it then, that beginners are so often taught to draw from real life?
A lot of art education is done incompetently, but there's nothing mutually exclusive between drawing from real life and learning to draw bottom-up. A competent teacher can explain to the student how to hold and guide a pencil, and use the simplest still life to train their sense of proportion (2D placement of points on paper). From there, the student can advance to drawing shapes representing the contours of the forms, and finally to drawing the individual forms themselves.

Every single good school for this focuses on the following skill sets.
1. Basic Sketching skills, touching on topics such as texture, form through the 6 basic forms and focal point
2. Perspective
3. Character design, which includes anatomy, simple/complex, stretch and pull, design and form language
4. Rendering skills
Lastly
5. Basic 3D skills like UV Mapping and modelling

>am I wrong or is this total bullshit?
It's not total bullshit in the sense that there are more and less effective ways of presenting a subject and conveying a mood by certain placement of objects on the page, but this type of extensive geometric-patterning in hope of finding some mystical formula is pure magical thinking. As an exercise: take any image you consider "well-composed" and draw a bunch of random lines and curves. The more of them you draw, the more likely something "significant" is going to be placed on one of them. The rest is confirmation bias.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475672
I'm the same.
Just tough it out isn't working if you are like me. I need to feel passionate about something and anxiety blocks me completely.

First you need to get rid of your anxiety. This is hard...but you need to forgive yourself for not meeting your expectation. Work on accepting that you will get better with time but it won't be now. But everytime you draw you will get there eventually. So stop focusing on what you want your picture to be and focus on the small improvements you make on the way. This of course is not simple to do and you have to force yourself to reframe your mindset everytime it reverse into anxiety, self doubt and feeling negative. If you fail to do that..forgive yourself for this to. This is important.

the second thing is to do what I want to do. If i'm motivated everything feels possible. If i'm not...everything seems insurmentable.
But i'm not motivated. Yes...that's why you will need to find a way to make it motivating.
Maybe what would motivate you is to get better at values. So start with values studies...procrastinate...but in the right direction...then try to apply what you learn on what you should do. If it's not good. Redo values studies and try again etc...

Well how to motivate yourself is not easy...but it's possible.

And the last part is. Accept that what you want and what the client needs aren't the same thing. The client is happy with mediocre most of the time and you well get what you want...but not now. But if you trust the process and keep at it eventually you'll get there.
You'll get other clients later. Don't bet everything you have on this one comission...it won't happen anyway.

Be patient. And if you can't get to work because you avoid feeling bad. Then start with forcing yourself to feel bad and sit with the bad feeling for a while...then stop and do something. Then you repeat sitting still and confronting your bad feelings...until you'll get used to confronting those feelings.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6475504
you can tell if an artist is working off of a sketch or not
if it's very clean, smooth and precise, it's made on top of a sketch, if it's "rough," "expressive" or "loose," it's freehand if the artist is experienced enough, most will do both
your average published, conventionally styled manga(and western comics too, really) is relatively finnicky and laborious to make, full of magic tricks and techniques that have more to do with crafts than arts, to the point where the transition to digital(which is what i'm assuming you're referring to when you say "traditional") adds only a little bit of extra "artificiality" to it, because it always has been, these aren't impressionist ear cutter paintings, they're products made to a standard

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6460785
I think that the process of painting/drawing a pictore is so different from prompting that you have to doubt if the people labelling themselves as "ai artists" right now would ever have gone through the trouble of learning how to draw properly without ai. Sure, some of them were trying to learn it at some point but so were a lot of other people who never had the patience to actually become good at it and eventually ended up moving on to other things. Promting just happened to what this partucular group moved on to but I seriously doubt many of them would have become "proper" artists if not for ai. They'd more likely just be playing video games or shitposting on reddit instead.

In the end, comparing drawing to prompting is like comparing someone taking a photo of a landscape to someone making a painting of that same landscape. Sure, they might come up with results that look similar but the process in itself is so different that one person would most likely not enjoy what the other is doing and vice versa. Are there some people who like both painting and photography? Sure, just like some will combine the two into a single artwork but there are also plenty of people who only enjoy one of the two and there's nothing wrong with that. It's simply two different ways to produce an image.

Not saying this to defend ai by the way, I still think the way it was produced and marketed is shady as fuck and I'm all for regulations to stop these schizos from creating their AGI dystopia. But I also think saying "why would you prompt if you can just learn how to draw" is disingenuous in a way, since most of the current prompters likely would never have learned how to draw anyway, with or without the existence of ai

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6459289
It's actually doing the opposite. Most AI artists are just shit at using the AI, but it's genuinely leading us to more variation.
That's part of why the hysteria around all this started with Artstation-type "industry" artists. They spent their careers cultivating their styles to be corporate-friendly so they can hop from temporary job to temporary job brownnosing and trying to win based on groveling to art directors for a perma spot. They're literally all almost interchangeable though, by design. Companies want to be able to let people go and hire new ones without the brand image changing much. Think of how Wizards of the Coast's Magic The Gathering changed around when they started letting go all the trad painters in the mid 2000s, vs how little their "look" has really changed since around 2010.

I have seen people use AI to mishmash all kinds of crazy things and it really speaks volumes to how many niches are out there for artists to jump on. You want to draw coomer art in the old SNK style from the 90s? There's people who would LOVE that. You want to draw something like a combo of Saint Seiya and the chunkiness Jack Kirby? Someone out there is going to want you to draw their OC like that.

Most of the AI shit is generic but most peoples' tastes are generic because most people don't actually give a shit about art or interact with it outside of TV/Movies and SOMETIMES AAA games. More art exposure = more taste developed = more people wanting their specific custom ideas made by non-ai artists (and/or becoming artists themselves).

>>6469073
Yea I constantly see shit nobody was making before.
You show me people who were painting a combo of 1800s garden scenes with anime women.
You show me the artist who was making "[Thing] as an 80s [genre] movie" before.

The fact is nobody was doing this shit before and now the people with fucked up ideas can struggle with trying to describe it to a dumb text interpreter to get some semblence of a visual output, making something close enough to communicate "the idea of it" with even modest skill. And then maybe they'll take that to a non-AI artist as a reference!

Doing that process with a non-AI artist is immensely risky on both a cost and time level, for BOTH the artist and the other person. The artist may have to deal with numerous corrections, and the commissioner would have to first scour the internet for someone who CAN do such a thing and gather reference material that fits it, before having the interaction difficulty with an artist, the monetary cost, and having to pay for more corrections or going to another artist after for "this but better" if the experience and result was lackluster. Skipping that whole first step to the "this but better" part is huge for productivity for both commissioners AND artists.
